Application forms
Legal documents
Denver (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand written on frontside top "Sept 25". Stapmed on frontside bottom " Recieved Oct 4, 1906, Accepted Nov. 3/06, Admitted, Discharged, Left, Died." Handwritten on the frontside bottom "P. Sandomire". Handwritten on backside, center section " Died Dec 3/06 in the Sanatorium while an Emergency patient, see application #360"

Application for admittance to JCRS filled out by hand for Sara Silverman. Information on the form includes her age, birth place, occupation, residence, marital status, children's ages, nearest relatives, and signed by Sara Silverman. Stamped near the bottom of the front is "Recieved Oct 4 1906, Accepted Nov. 3/06, Admitted, Dischared, Left, Died." Hand written at the bottom is "P. Sandomire." Hand written on the top is "Sept 25." The back of the form has sections titled "Report of Medical Advisory Board" and "Report of Executive Committee," both are blank. The middle section of the back has "Case #30" penciled at the top and rest of the form is filled out by hand in ink. It reads, "No. 331, Application of, Sara Silverman,Recieved Oct 4 1906, Date of Admission, Date of Discharge." Had written on the top of the middle section is "Case #211 (See inside App #360) stamped on the top of the middle section is "Emergency". Had written on the bottom of the middle section "Died Dec. 3/06 in the Sanatorium while an Emergency patient, use application #360. ADD"
oai_dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item, (application), Poor, Aplication has tear on top half going from the right side of the document almost to the middle of the document. The tear goes through wording on the application, however the application is still legible., 30 x 22 centimeters

Handwritten letter from Mrs. H. Levite of the Hebrew Ladies Relieve Association to Dr. Spivak at JCRS, dated November 13, 1906. The letter thanks Dr. Spivak and the JCRS for taking the suggestion of the Hebrew Ladies Relief Association and working to admit Mrs. Bernick. It requests that upon her arrival in Denver, Mrs. Bernick should be admitted to their tent, and in the mean time JCRS should secure her room and board. Letters

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typed letter from JCRS to Mr. Max Bieler. The letter states that after a conversation with Max Bieler in which stated that he never denied that his fater is a well to do man, there is nothing left to do but discharge Mr. Max Bieler from the Sanatorium on the first of September 1907. The letter states that Mr. Bieler was at the Sanatorium for eight months and now it is someone else's chance. Because of the financial status of his parent he should have been discharged a long time ago because the sanatorium patients are mostly penniless and friendless. The letter is not signed but "Secretary" is typed at the bottom.

oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Typed letter from JCRS to Mr. Julius Ginewsky, Secretary of the Share Thora Lodge #219 I.O.B.A. The letter was written to inform Mr. Ginewsky that since Mr. Battock was discharged from the Sanatorium he has had difficulty finding work in Denver because the supply of labor is greater than the work demand. Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (U.S.)
Patient Records
Letters
Denver (Colo.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Handwritten next to the signature is "write to" with an errow pointing to the signature

A typed letter of introduction from B Thomashefsky to JCRS for Samuell Kravitz. The letter states that Mr. Kravitz traveled to Denver to obtain relief for his condition and is requesting help from JCRS. He has been sick for two year and is a cap maker by trade. The leter is signed Bores Thomaskefsky. Below the typed portion of the letter is a paragraph written in Yiddish and signed by B Thomashefky.
oai_dc:dc.dc:language: Document is in both English and Yiddish
